posts.p_message: If you are moving to Abu Dhabi with Family and want to transfer your kid to be in school here, these information can be useful for you‚ÄºÔ∏è1Ô∏è‚É£ There are 2 Type of school : Public and Private School.Public Schools are government-funded, UAE Curriculum. Main language is arabic, but English is also emphasized. It can be for emirati or expatriate, but only for emirati the school is free.Private (can be international schools) , the students can be both expatriate and Emirati. The curriculum varies such as British, American, IB, Indian curriculum, etc.2Ô∏è‚É£ In public schools, usually boys and girls are separately divided by gender. Private schools have mixed gender on classes. But it‚Äôs all depend on the school. 3Ô∏è‚É£ Different curriculum have different rule. In the British curriculum, children aged 5-6 years are belongs to ‚ÄúYear 1‚Äù, while in American curriculum they are included as ‚ÄúKindergarten 2‚Äù. British have 1 up category level than american curriculum. Grade 12 in American equivalent with Year 13 in british curriculum

posts.p_message: Hey mammies. Does anyone have a child who didn‚Äôt attend nursery/preschool and went only to school when they were 5? I guess that‚Äôs when mandatory education starts in UAE? Did you face any issues/ were schools asking for preschool/ FS1/2 certificates? I‚Äôm really struggling, signed up my son for nursery and it‚Äôs a constant battle, we‚Äôre both flying so the separation anxiety is there (for all of us) and he really doesn‚Äôt enjoy going there. It‚Äôs a great montessori nursery with amazing team of teachers but he‚Äôs only 3, back home we don‚Äôt send kids to nursery until 5/6 unless people don‚Äôt have any other option and work full time. I‚Äôm constantly stressed about mornings and he is too to I think I decided I will not continue until he‚Äôs older and ready. I just want to see if schools (especially in Dubai) make a fuss about not being ‚Äúprepared‚Äù. Thank you.

posts.p_message: Hi. I'm a mum of 3 boys. We moved to the UAE in 2022 from qatar. Since then I've been looking for a good affordable school for my kids. My elder one was in Delhi public school in qatar , which was one of the best cbse Indian curriculum schools in qatar. They had ethical values, qualified teachers and very high standards in every manner. After moving to UAE, we have always been shifting schools.  I don't understand why schools still use tablets and online application. I don't understand why schools don't use textbooks. I don't understand why teachers cannot control kids in school. Kids just go to school to play tabs and take toys to school. I wonder why teachers don't warn them ! As a parent I do my best at home until the second they get into their school bus. But after that  how can I help?  Can someone pls kindly advise a good affordable school ?? I don't understand the need to have a separate education for boys and girls. They little boys don't even know how to respect girls. Vice versa. Won't this impact their future ?

posts.p_message: My top tips for moving to Dubai. Relocating as a family can feel like a minefield there are so many things to tick off the never ending to do list it can feel so overwhelming at times! I often get asked for advice on moving to Dubai as a family and so I decided to share my top tips!I would always reccomend starting with schools as it‚Äôs so important to find one you love for your child! Schools in Dubai are very busy with so many people currently moving here so I do reccomend contacting them to arrange a tour. Either virtually or in person and once you have picked one you love enroll your child!Traffic in Dubai is a nightmare so I always recommend living close to school.
